prior_works.title: Unbalanced Optimal Transport: Dynamic and Kantorovich Formulations
prior_works.authors: Lénaïc Chizat, Gabriel Peyré, Bernhard Schmitzer, François-Xavier Vialard
prior_works.role: Foundational theory of unbalanced OT with mass variation via f-divergence penalization and dynamic (reaction–transport) viewpoints.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s treatment of unequal masses on graphs draws directly on Chizat et al.’s variational/Kantorovich frameworks for unbalanced OT, which the authors reference as the marginal-discrepancy penalization baseline they aim to simplify beyond two-level optimization.

prior_works.title: Optimal Transport in Competition with Reaction: The Hellinger–Kantorovich Distance and Geodesic Curves
prior_works.authors: Marco Liero, Alexander Mielke, Giuseppe Savaré
prior_works.role: Introduces the HK/WFR metric as a rigorous reaction–transport geometry for unbalanced measures.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The proposed Orlicz–Sobolev formulation inherits the reaction–transport intuition of HK to model mass change, adapting it to an Orlicz geometric structure on graphs.

prior_works.title: Scaling Algorithms for Unbalanced Transport Problems
prior_works.authors: Lénaïc Chizat, Gabriel Peyré, Bernhard Schmitzer, François-Xavier Vialard
prior_works.role: Computational framework (generalized Sinkhorn) for unbalanced OT via marginal penalties.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The authors explicitly contrast their approach with generalized Sinkhorn-style two-level schemes, motivating an Orlicz–Sobolev alternative that avoids the resulting nested optimization complexity on graphs.

prior_works.title: Gradient Flows of the Entropy for Finite Markov Chains
prior_works.role: Establishes transport/gradient-flow geometry on discrete graphs via a discrete 2-Wasserstein-like structure.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By working on graph metric spaces, the paper leverages the discrete OT/gradient-flow viewpoint pioneered by Maas to define and compute transport along graph edges within their Orlicz–Sobolev model.

prior_works.title: Free Boundary Regularity in Optimal Partial Transport
prior_works.authors: Luis A. Caffarelli, Robert J. McCann, Alessio Figalli
prior_works.role: Classical mass-constraint approach to differing total masses via partial transport.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The authors cite mass-constraint strategies as a path to unbalanced OT that increases problem complexity; partial OT provides this paradigm the new method seeks to supersede with a unified Orlicz–Sobolev formulation.

prior_works.title: On the Wasserstein–Orlicz Space
prior_works.role: Mathematical foundation of Wasserstein–Orlicz geometry replacing L^p growth by general Young functions.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The core idea of endowing transport with an Orlicz geometric structure directly relies on the Wasserstein–Orlicz theory, which the paper extends to unbalanced settings on graphs.

prior_works.title: Generalized Sobolev Transport for Probability Measures on Graphs
prior_works.authors: Tam Le, Truyen Nguyen, Hideitsu Hino, Kenji Fukumizu
prior_works.role: Introduces GST as a scalable graph-based transport framework for balanced (equal-mass) measures.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The present work explicitly tackles GST’s rigidity by extending it beyond equal-mass constraints to nonnegative/unbalanced measures through an Orlicz–Sobolev redesign.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s key contribution—an efficient Orlicz–Sobolev approach for transporting unbalanced measures on graphs—sits at the intersection of three lines of work: unbalanced optimal transport (UOT), Orlicz-based transport geometry, and discrete transport/gradient-flow structures on graphs. On the UOT side, Chizat et al. formalized unbalanced transport in both dynamic and Kantorovich terms, while Liero–Mielke–Savaré’s Hellinger–Kantorovich metric grounded mass variation via reaction–transport dynamics. These works also motivated practical algorithms: generalized Sinkhorn scaling for unbalanced problems, which the authors argue induces a two-level optimization burden, and earlier mass-constraint paradigms such as partial OT that add problem rigidity.

The second pillar is Orlicz geometry for transport, where Wasserstein–Orlicz theory replaces L^p growth by general Young functions to capture richer geometries. Building on this mathematical foundation, the present paper leverages Orlicz structure to model nuanced costs and robustness (e.g., to outliers) while avoiding the computational pitfalls of standard UOT penalization.

Finally, the graph setting connects to discrete OT and gradient flows: Maas’s discrete transport geometry provides the blueprint for formulating transport along edges with appropriate continuity equations and Sobolev structures. Prior work on Generalized Sobolev Transport (GST) offered a scalable graph-based scheme but was restricted to equal-mass measures; this paper addresses that rigidity by integrating Orlicz geometry with a Sobolev-flow formulation that natively handles nonnegative/unbalanced measures, yielding a single-level, scalable approach tailored to graph metric spaces.
